problem: Given that $$(x+y+z)(xy+xz+yz)=25$$and that $$x^2(y+z)+y^2(x+z)+z^2(x+y)=7$$for real numbers $x$, $y$, and $z$, what is the value of $xyz$?
solution:
Expanding the first given equation using the distributive property, we have \begin{align*}
25&=(x+y+z)(xy+xz+yz)\\&=x(xy+xz+yz)+y(xy+xz+yz)+z(xy+xz+yz)\\
&=x^2y+x^2z+xyz+xy^2+xyz+y^2z+xyz+xz^2+yz^2\\
&=3xyz+x^2y+x^2z+xy^2+y^2z+xz^2+yz^2
\end{align*}Expanding the second given equation using the distributive property, we have \begin{align*}
7&=x^2(y+z)+y^2(x+z)+z^2(x+y)\\
&=x^2y+x^2z+xy^2+y^2z+xz^2+yz^2.\end{align*}We substitute the equation $$7=x^2y+x^2z+xy^2+y^2z+xz^2+yz^2$$into the expanded form of the first given equation to get \[25=3xyz+7\]or $xyz=\boxed{6}$.
chatgpt_solution:
Using the first equation,
$$\left(x^2+y^2+z^2+2xy+2xz+2yz\right)(xy+xz+yz)=25.$$Expanding this equation gives $$x^3y+x^3z+xy^3+xy^2z+x^2yz+y^3z+xyz^2+yz^3+2x^2y^2+2x^2z^2+2y^2z^2+4xyz(x+y+z)=25.$$Using the second equation,
$$x^2(y+z)+y^2(x+z)+z^2(x+y)=7,$$and expanding gives $$x^2y+x^2z+xy^2+xyz+y^2z+yz^2+x^2y+y^2z+xyz+z^2x+xz^2+xyz^2=7.$$Simplifying the "expanded" versions of the original two equations and setting them equal gives $$x^3y+x^3z+xy^3+xy^2z+x^2yz+y^3z+xyz^2+yz^3+2x^2y^2+2x^2z^2+2y^2z^2+4xyz(x+y+z)$$$$=x^2y+x^2z+xy^2+xyz+y^2z+yz^2+x^2y+y^2z+xyz+z^2x+xz^2+xyz^2.$$Arranging similar terms,
\begin{align*} x^3y+x^3z+xy^3+x^2yz+y^3z+xyz^2+yz^3+4x^2y^2+4x^2z^2+4y^2z^2-6xyz&=0, \\ (x+y+z)(xy+xz+yz)(x^2+y^2+z^2+xy+xz+yz-2xyz)&=0, \\ (xy+xz+yz)(7-2xyz)&=0. \end{align*}From the solution to problem 13, the system $(x+y+z)(xy+xz+yz)=0$ and $x^2(y+z)+y^2(x+z)+z^2(x+y)=0$ implies that one of $x+y+z=0$, $xy+xz+yz=0$, and $x^2+y^2+z^2+xy+xz+yz=0$ holds. Since $$x^2+y^2+z^2+xy+xz+yz=\frac{1}{2}\left((x+y)^2+(y+z)^2+(z+x)^2\right)>0,$$we must have $x+y+z=0$. But, by AM-GM, \begin{align*}
0=x+y+z&\ge 3\sqrt[3]{xyz}, \\
0&\ge xyz.
\end{align*}Equality is achieved when $x+y+z=x^2+y^2+z^2=xy+xz+yz=0$, or $(x,y,z)=(-t,-t,t)$ for some real $t$, so the answer is $\boxed{0}$.
